description:
This PR improves unstructured mesh support in yt. Due to some merging issues on BB, this PR includes the changes from the (now declined) [PR #1653](https://bitbucket.org/yt_analysis/yt/pull-requests/1653/exodus-ii-frontend/diff) from @astrohckr implementing an Exodus II frontend. In addition, it also does the following:

Slices have been hooked up and work with the normal yt syntax.

The pixelizer has been tested with different types of datasets, and made more robust in the process via tweaks and bugfixes.

The unstructured mesh rendering has been improved. In particular, ZBuffering is now implemented, which allows multiple meshes to be rendered on the same scene using the same syntax as the rest of the VR refactor. In principle, we can now combine mesh renderings with other render source types as well.

Mesh lines annotations can be added, both for slices and for renderings.

Support for ray-tracing high-order geometries has been added.

New 2D element samplers have been added and hooked up to the pixelizer, allowing us visualize 2D meshes.

A couple of VR bugs have been fixed. In particular, the add operation for ZBuffers was broken, this fixes it and adds a unit test that would have caught the failure.

Some tweaks to the Exodus II frontend have been made. First, because multiple time steps can exist in the same output file, I've added an optional step argument to the load command that allows you to specify which step you want. Second, I've established a convection for how to deal with different meshes as field_types, e.g. ('connect1', 'diffused'), ('connect2', 'diffused'), etc. Feedback on these two choices is particularly welcome.

More documentation has been added.

More tests have been added.

Finally, this PR also includes some changes that were made to the development branch that haven't been merged into the experimental branch.
title: More unstructured mesh work

content.raw:
I believe the new code in this PR is just the Exodus-II frontend. @atmyers can you confirm that?

That should be relatively easy to review since it's pretty much self-contained.
content.html:
I believe the new code in this PR is just the Exodus-II frontend. Andrew Myers can you confirm that?

That should be relatively easy to review since it's pretty much self-contained.

content.raw:
No, there are other changes as well, mostly related to volume rendering and slicing, and also the test and docs about the unstructured mesh support. The Exodus II frontend stuff has actually already been reviewed and was about to be merged in, but because of a Bitbucket mishap we had to fold it in with this PR. 

I'm not happy about all of the PRs from dev in here, either, but most of those had to be in in order for the tests to pass on the experimental head, since there have been a lot of changes to the SPH answer tests recently that didn't make it over to experimental.
content.html:
No, there are other changes as well, mostly related to volume rendering and slicing, and also the test and docs about the unstructured mesh support. The Exodus II frontend stuff has actually already been reviewed and was about to be merged in, but because of a Bitbucket mishap we had to fold it in with this PR.

I'm not happy about all of the PRs from dev in here, either, but most of those had to be in in order for the tests to pass on the experimental head, since there have been a lot of changes to the SPH answer tests recently that didn't make it over to experimental.

content.raw: Yeah, I'm not really sure what's up with this - it passed on my local machine.
content.html: Yeah, I'm not really sure what's up with this - it passed on my local machine.

content.raw: So the tests are being done against the "dev" head even though this is in the "experimental" head?  Or are you making changes to code that touches on the SPH answer tests?  I figured the unstructured mesh work wasn't considered either SPH or grid-based.
content.html: So the tests are being done against the "dev" head even though this is in the "experimental" head? Or are you making changes to code that touches on the SPH answer tests? I figured the unstructured mesh work wasn't considered either SPH or grid-based.

content.raw:
There aren't separate answers for the dev and experimental heads. Andrew is porting the changes from the dev head that changed the answers relative to what's in the experimental head to get the answers tests to pass.

In principle we could also fix this by having a separate set of answers for the experimental head, but since we expect the experimental head to be relatively short-lived after next week we decided at the last google hangout to just go ahead and port the necessary changes to get the tests to pass on the experimental head.

content.raw: That makes sense.  The only problem I foresee is if there are substantial VR tests in the dev head that won't pass for the experimental code, but I guess we can just ignore those for now.
content.html: That makes sense. The only problem I foresee is if there are substantial VR tests in the dev head that won't pass for the experimental code, but I guess we can just ignore those for now.

content.raw: The VR tests are unit tests, so no need to store static answers separate from the codebase.
content.html: The VR tests are unit tests, so no need to store static answers separate from the codebase.

content.raw:
For a while I've wanted to add a concept of a unitless simulation. This way a frontend or individual user could say that their data is unitless so plots would be displayed without units and data object accesses would return data in code units. Things would still have dimensions, so you couldn't add a pressure to a density, for example.

I haven't had a research reason to add this, but I think it's something reasonable for a sprint. If you want to chat more about it I'm happy to do so.
content.html:
For a while I've wanted to add a concept of a unitless simulation. This way a frontend or individual user could say that their data is unitless so plots would be displayed without units and data object accesses would return data in code units. Things would still have dimensions, so you couldn't add a pressure to a density, for example.

I haven't had a research reason to add this, but I think it's something reasonable for a sprint. If you want to chat more about it I'm happy to do so.

content.raw: I'd be interested in helping out with that, both for this and because I like to do my own simulations that way, too. In the meantime, what is the right way to handle this here? Am I correct that the code units have to be set to something, even if it's bogus?
content.html: I'd be interested in helping out with that, both for this and because I like to do my own simulations that way, too. In the meantime, what is the right way to handle this here? Am I correct that the code units have to be set to something, even if it's bogus?

content.raw:
That's right. I think assuming CGS like you have it here is reasonable.

This might be a big enough change to require a YTEP, I'd be happy to collaborate with you on that.

I think we'd need to create a new `Dataset` attribute, something like `ds.unitless` which is either `True` or `False`. We would then need to go through the data selection and plotting machinery and add checks for `ds.unitless` and then special-case code that adds units to plots and the return values from data object accesses. We can also discuss what other semantics we might want to think about enforcing for unitless simulations.
content.html:
That's right. I think assuming CGS like you have it here is reasonable.

This might be a big enough change to require a YTEP, I'd be happy to collaborate with you on that.

I think we'd need to create a new Dataset attribute, something like ds.unitless which is either True or False. We would then need to go through the data selection and plotting machinery and add checks for ds.unitless and then special-case code that adds units to plots and the return values from data object accesses. We can also discuss what other semantics we might want to think about enforcing for unitless simulations.

content.raw: I think I've fixed all of the issues with the images not getting embedded in the documentation. Thanks, @ngoldbaum, for pointing them out. I also simplified the API for annotating mesh lines on slices, as @MatthewTurk suggested. Finally, I've made the setup.py script that build the cython extensions respest the EMBREE_DIR environment variable, so that you don't have to pass in CFLAGS and LDFLAGS all the time in order to recompile.
content.html: I think I've fixed all of the issues with the images not getting embedded in the documentation. Thanks, Nathan Goldbaum, for pointing them out. I also simplified the API for annotating mesh lines on slices, as Matthew Turk suggested. Finally, I've made the setup.py script that build the cython extensions respest the EMBREE_DIR environment variable, so that you don't have to pass in CFLAGS and LDFLAGS all the time in order to recompile.

content.raw:
My thinking was this: these messages will only get printed when compiling the Cython extensions in utilities/lib. If the build is successful, people won't notice the extra output at all, but if the build fails, the presence of these warnings in the output might help us debug. 

That said, I'm not attached to having this. Would it be better to just have this function be silent?
content.html:
My thinking was this: these messages will only get printed when compiling the Cython extensions in utilities/lib. If the build is successful, people won't notice the extra output at all, but if the build fails, the presence of these warnings in the output might help us debug.

That said, I'm not attached to having this. Would it be better to just have this function be silent?

content.html: As long as we're adding new print statements, can we make these py3 compatible and just toss some parenthesis on?

content.raw: Hmm, I'm surprised we have to link from `.so` to `.dylib`.
content.html: Hmm, I'm surprised we have to link from .so to .dylib.

content.raw: This is more of a style thing, but I thought we could do `im.save` too, but maybe not.
content.html: This is more of a style thing, but I thought we could do im.save too, but maybe not.

content.raw: These can all be imported from `yt.visualization.volume_rendering.api`
content.html: These can all be imported from yt.visualization.volume_rendering.api

content.raw: Not necessary now, but sometimes we have an offset that we use for `mesh_id` and the like.  Then you can iterate up to `len(self.meshes)` and use the offset for i.
content.html: Not necessary now, but sometimes we have an offset that we use for mesh_id and the like. Then you can iterate up to len(self.meshes) and use the offset for i.

content.raw: My personal preference is to use explicitly the numpy types, like `np.float64_t` instead of `double`, but I don't think it's necessary here.
content.html: My personal preference is to use explicitly the numpy types, like np.float64_t instead of double, but I don't think it's necessary here.

content.raw: Hi @atmyers , this looks really, really awesome.  I have reviewed it, and while I did go over the math and think it looks right, I think your test cases catch the most important issues, and I'm ready to see this merged in.  Thank you so much!
content.html: Hi Andrew Myers , this looks really, really awesome. I have reviewed it, and while I did go over the math and think it looks right, I think your test cases catch the most important issues, and I'm ready to see this merged in. Thank you so much!

content.raw: Ultimately, I'll rework these examples to use sc.save(), like the other VR examples do. That option wasn't available when I wrote these example scripts, IIRC.
content.html: Ultimately, I'll rework these examples to use sc.save(), like the other VR examples do. That option wasn't available when I wrote these example scripts, IIRC.

content.raw: I remember that we had to do this, but I can try to find an easier way.
content.html: I remember that we had to do this, but I can try to find an easier way.

content.raw: Yep, will fix this.
content.html: Yep, will fix this.

content.raw: Will fix this too.
content.html: Will fix this too.

content.raw:
I thought we wanted to avoid internal transitive imports from api.py files. This is mentioned in the code style guide, for example.

Personally I find it easier to directly import things from the file where they are defined. It's easy enough to feel the codebase if and when something internal needs to be changed.
content.html:
I thought we wanted to avoid internal transitive imports from api.py files. This is mentioned in the code style guide, for example.

Personally I find it easier to directly import things from the file where they are defined. It's easy enough to feel the codebase if and when something internal needs to be changed.

content.raw: I thought having imports from the `api` files in the docs was okay.
content.html: I thought having imports from the api files in the docs was okay.

content.html: Sorry, commented from my phone, didn't realize this was a doc file. Please ignore.

content.html: I plan on going through the Cython for the unstructured mesh stuff and switching over to memoryviews, since that is a lot more readable. I can make this change at time. Why do you prefer the numpy types?

content.html: Oh yes, I agree.
